aoop.asteroids.model

Class Game

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.Observable
      • aoop.asteroids.model.Game
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    public class Game
extends java.util.Observable
implements java.lang.Runnable
    The game class is the backbone of all simulations of the asteroid game. It contains all game object and keeps track of some other required variables in order to specify game rules.

    The game rules are as follows:

    • All game objects are updated according to their own rules every game tick.
    • Every 200th game tick a new asteroid is spawn. An asteroid cannot spawn within a 50 pixel radius of the player.
    • There is a maximum amount of asteroids that are allowed to be active simultaneously. Asteroids that spawn from destroying a larger asteroid do count towards this maximum, but are allowed to spawn if maximum is exceeded.
    • Destroying an asteroid spawns two smaller asteroids. I.e. large asteroids spawn two medium asteroids and medium asteroids spawn two small asteroids upon destruction.
    • The player dies upon colliding with either a buller or an asteroid.
    • Destroying every 5th asteroid increases the asteroid limit by 1, increasing the difficulty.

    This class implements Runnable, so all simulations will be run in its own thread. This class extends Observable in order to notify the view element of the program, without keeping a reference to those objects.

      • update

        private void update()
        Method invoked at every game tick. It updates all game objects first. Then it adds a bullet if the player is firing. Afterwards it checks all objects for collisions and removes the destroyed objects. Finally the game tick counter is updated and a new asteroid is spawn upon every 200th game tick.

      • addRandomAsteroid

        private void addRandomAsteroid()
        Adds a randomly sized asteroid at least 50 pixels removed from the player.

      • checkCollisions

        private void checkCollisions()
        Checks all objects for collisions and marks them as destroyed upon col- lision. All objects can collide with objects of a different type, but not with objects of the same type. I.e. bullets cannot collide with bullets etc.

      • increaseScore

        private void increaseScore()
        Increases the score of the player by one and updates asteroid limit when required.

      • removeDestroyedObjects

        private void removeDestroyedObjects()
        Removes all destroyed objects. Destroyed asteroids increase the score and spawn two smaller asteroids if it wasn't a small asteroid. New asteroids are faster than their predecessor and travel in opposite direction.

      • gameOver

        private boolean gameOver()
        Returns whether the game is over. The game is over when the spaceship is destroyed.
        Returns:
        true if game is over, false otherwise.

      • abort

        public void abort()
        Aborts the game.
        See Also:
        run()

      • run

        public void run()
        This method allows this object to run in its own thread, making sure that the same thread will not perform non essential computations for the game. The thread will not stop running until the program is quit. If the game is aborted or the player died, it will wait 100 milliseconds before reevaluating and continuing the simulation.

        While the game is not aborted and the player is still alive, it will measure the time it takes the program to perform a game tick and wait 40 minus execution time milliseconds to do it all over again. This allows the game to update every 40th millisecond, thus keeping a steady 25 frames per second.

        Decrease waiting time to increase fps. Note however, that all game mechanics will be faster as well. I.e. asteroids will travel faster, bullets will travel faster and the spaceship may not be as easy to control.

        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable
